item.title: Installing Software
item.description: Package managers The process of installing software on Linux can vary depending on the distribution you are using. Here is a general overview of the common methods used to install software on different Linux distributions: Debian and Ubuntu: Software is typically installed using the apt package manager. Low level manager is normally dpkg Red Hat and Fedora: Software is typically installed using the yum package manager. Low level manager is normally rpm SUSE Family: Software is typically installed using the zypper package manager.

item.title: Shell
item.description: The shell in linux is a program that allows the user to interact with the underlying OS by sending text commands. Popular shells include: Bourne Again Shell (bash) zsh sh Current shell can be determined reading the environment variable $SHELL. Furthermore, using chshAllows one to change the shell for the user Assumed shell In these docs, it is assumed the shell is bash Command types Command come in two types. item.title: Checking the System
item.description: Below is a list of common operations to check the current status of a linux system Hardware Some general information about the machine can be obtained by using the uname command.
